text: lower growth higher prices and more
unemployment we will all be hit by a
vote to leave the EU according to the
Bank of England
it's what Mark Carney calls the elephant
in the room and today the governor of
the Bank gave a stark warning a vote to
leave the European Union could have
material economic effects on the
exchange rate on demand and on the
economy's supply potential so this
combination of influences on demand
supply in the exchange rate could lead
to a materially lower path for growth
and a notably higher path for inflation
previously the bank had thought growth
this year would be 2.2 percent it thinks
now that's already slowed to one and a
half percent and a vote to leave could
push the economy into a recession the
bank says that could be a sharp fall in
sterling higher inflation and higher
unemployment but the leave campaign
dismissed those concerns if we leave the
European Union every report including
the IMF and everyone else said the UK
economy will continue to grow and so the
second thing I'd make about the governor
of the Bank of England I'd be very
careful about his entering the fray on
this one because whatever else forecasts
are almost always wrong if anybody can
tell me they know what the global
economy is going to be doing over the
next year let alone next ten years I
have to say either their soothsayers or
they've got some link with God but the
prime minister says the Bank of England
has sent a very clear message now they
are totally independent from government
their job is to tell it like it is and
to warn of risks in the economy and they
couldn't be more clear that there is a
risk the Bank of England has rejected
any suggestion that it's interfering in
politics and says it will try to offset
the potential hit to the economy if the
UK votes to leave the EU but it says
there are limits to what it can do John
T Blume BBC News
